name: Bitcoin Fundamentals
description: Understand the thesis behind the 1129-day SMA and why Bitcoin serves as pristine collateral
graduationStandard: Articulate why 1129 days + 12% withdrawal rate creates perpetual income

lessons.title: What is Bitcoin?
lessons.objective: Understand digital scarcity, proof of work, and the 21 million cap

sections.content: Bitcoin is the first truly scarce digital asset. Unlike traditional currencies that can be printed infinitely, Bitcoin has a hard cap of 21 million coins that will ever exist. This scarcity is enforced by mathematics and a decentralized network of computers, not by any government or institution.

Proof of Work (PoW) is Bitcoin's consensus mechanism. Miners expend real-world energy to secure the network and validate transactions. This energy expenditure creates an unforgeable costliness - you cannot fake or shortcut the work required. This is what gives Bitcoin its trustless security.

content: 21 million cap - enforced by code, not policy
Proof of Work - energy expenditure creates security
Decentralized - no single point of control
Trustless - verify, don't trust
Halvings - emission rate cuts in half every ~4 years

questions.question: What makes Bitcoin scarce?
options: A hard cap of 21 million enforced by code

questions.question: What does Proof of Work provide?

lessons.title: Wrapped BTC Variants
lessons.objective: Compare WBTC, cbBTC, and tBTC custody models and risk profiles

sections.content: Native Bitcoin cannot run on Ethereum. To use BTC in DeFi, it must be 'wrapped' - locked in custody while an equivalent ERC-20 token is minted. Different wrapping solutions have different trust assumptions and risk profiles.

WBTC (Wrapped Bitcoin) uses BitGo as custodian. It's the most liquid but relies on a centralized entity. cbBTC uses Coinbase institutional custody - different custodian, same centralized model. tBTC uses threshold signatures across a decentralized network - no single custodian, but more technical complexity.

content: WBTC - BitGo custody, most liquid, centralized risk
cbBTC - Coinbase custody, institutional grade, centralized risk
tBTC - Threshold signatures, decentralized, technical complexity
Risk isolation - protocol deploys separately per collateral type
Choose based on your custody risk tolerance

questions.question: Why does the protocol deploy separately for each wrapped BTC type?
options: Risk isolation - custody failure in one doesn't affect others

questions.question: Which wrapped BTC uses decentralized custody?

lessons.title: The 1129-Day SMA
lessons.objective: Understand how the 1129-day Simple Moving Average transforms volatility into stability

sections.content: A Simple Moving Average (SMA) smooths price data by averaging values over a specific window. The 1129-day SMA averages Bitcoin's price over approximately 3 years and 1 month. This specific window was chosen based on historical analysis.

Analysis of every possible 1129-day window in Bitcoin's history (1,837 rolling samples) shows that 100% of them produced positive returns. The minimum return was +77.78%, mean return was +313.07%, and maximum was +902.96%. No other holding period has achieved this consistency.

content: 1129 days = ~3 years 1 month
100% positive returns across all 1,837 historical windows
Minimum return: +77.78%
Mean return: +313.07%
This is the thesis: time-averaging eliminates negative outcomes

questions.question: How many 1129-day windows in Bitcoin's history have shown positive returns?
What was the minimum return in any 1129-day window?
Why is 1129 days significant?
options: All historical windows of this length show positive returns

lessons.title: Volatility Inversion
lessons.objective: Learn how extreme volatility becomes a feature when time-averaged

sections.content: Bitcoin's volatility is legendary - 70-80% drawdowns and 300-900% gains are common. Traditional finance views this as unacceptable risk. But this volatility is precisely what enables the 1129-day thesis.

When you commit to holding for 1129 days, volatility works FOR you, not against you. The severe drawdowns create entry opportunities within your holding period, while the massive recoveries drive the consistently positive outcomes. Time transforms the volatility liability into an asset.

content: Short-term: 70-80% drawdowns possible
Long-term: 100% of 1129-day windows positive
Volatility enables the outsized returns
Time is the averaging mechanism - no oracle needed
This inversion is unique to Bitcoin's characteristics

questions.question: Why is Bitcoin's volatility actually beneficial for the 1129-day thesis?
options: Drawdowns create entry opportunities, recoveries drive positive outcomes

questions.question: What transforms volatility from liability to asset?

lessons.title: Market Cycles
lessons.objective: Understand Bitcoin's halving cycles and why bear markets are shorter than 1129 days

sections.content: Bitcoin operates on a predictable halving cycle. Approximately every 4 years (210,000 blocks), the mining reward is cut in half. This creates a supply shock that historically triggers bull markets. The pattern: halving -> supply reduction -> price increase -> excess -> bear market -> repeat.

Historical bear markets: 2014 (-86%), 2018 (-84%), 2022 (-77%). Each was severe but none lasted longer than 1129 days from peak to full recovery. The 1129-day window encompasses approximately 3/4 of a halving cycle, ensuring exposure to at least one significant recovery phase.

content: Halving every ~4 years reduces new supply by 50%
Historical drawdowns: -77% to -86%
All bear markets recovered within 1129 days
1129 days spans ~3/4 of a halving cycle
Long-term holders always rewarded if patient

questions.question: How often does Bitcoin's mining reward halving occur?
What is the significance of 1129 days relative to market cycles?
options: It spans ~3/4 of a cycle, ensuring recovery exposure
It's the shortest possible holding period

lessons.title: Pristine Collateral
lessons.objective: Understand why Bitcoin is ideal for perpetual withdrawal mechanisms

sections.content: Pristine collateral has three properties: verifiable scarcity, no counterparty risk in holding, and reliable value appreciation over time. Bitcoin uniquely satisfies all three. Gold has scarcity but is hard to verify. Stocks have growth but counterparty risk. Bonds have predictability but inflation risk.

For perpetual withdrawals to work, the collateral must appreciate faster than the withdrawal rate over time. At 12% annual withdrawal (1% monthly), Bitcoin's historical minimum return of +77.78% over 1129 days (annualized ~23%) provides substantial margin. This is why Bitcoin works where other assets cannot.

content: Verifiable scarcity - 21M cap enforced by code
No counterparty risk - hold your own keys
Reliable appreciation - 100% positive 1129-day windows
12% annual withdrawal requires ~12% appreciation to maintain
Historical minimum annualized: ~23%, well above 12%

questions.question: What makes Bitcoin 'pristine' collateral?
options: Verifiable scarcity + no counterparty risk + reliable long-term appreciation

questions.question: Why is 12% annual withdrawal sustainable with Bitcoin collateral?
options: Historical minimum annualized return (~23%) exceeds withdrawal rate (12%)

questions.question: What is the fundamental thesis of using Bitcoin for perpetual withdrawals?
